name: Grey Goo
description: Grey Goo is a real-time strategy (RTS) game that combines classic strategy mechanics and a balanced combat system with an emphasis on large-scale decision-making.
minimum_requirements: OS: 32-bit Windows 7 Processor: 3.5 GHz Intel Core i3 Dual Core or equivalent Memory: 4 GB RAM Graphics: 1024 MB DirectX 11 capable video card (GeForce GTX 460 or AMD Radeon HD 5870) DirectX: Version 11 Network: Broadband Internet connection Storage: 15 GB available space
recommended_requirements: OS: 64-bit Windows 7 Processor: 3 GHz Intel Core i5 Quad Core or equivalent Memory: 8 GB RAM Graphics: 1024 MB Direct3D 11 capable video card (GeForce GTX 570 or AMD Radeon HD 7870) DirectX: Version 11 Network: Broadband Internet connection Storage: 15 GB available space

reviews.review_text: Click  here  for the video.  Grey Goo is a new RTS from Petroglyph Games that removes unnecessary micro and brings back the classic gameplay you may remember from Command & Conquer's glory days.   Pros

It's good, not sure it's full price good, but it's good. Price point should have been closer to 39.00. Solid C&C style RTS. I like that the units don't have special powers that have to be kept up with. (why I suck so bad at SC2)  That being said, it's still pretty challenging in it's own right, just more straight forward, which I like.

This game is a well developed asymmetric RTS game, featuring 3 vastly different factions.  The humans are network based, all the constructs are linked and the game-play is heavily advantagous for those who prefer the turtle approach thanks to the turrets and the compact design their playstyle promotes. They are also the only faction capable of teleporting 6 units at once to any spot on the map where you have visibility allowing you to quickly reinforce troops if needed. Their elite unit sends a laser beem straight forward in a line, damaging any enemy ground unit (imho. this is the weakest elite unit, but they have air-superiority anyways thanks to their airplanes and how small their storages for the airplanes are).  On the completely opposite side this this is the Goo, the playstyle of the goo focuses on aggressive hit-and-run tactics, their elite unit can cause serious havoc and is also able to climb any obstacle and destroy enemy buildings and units by simply being around them. They are very strong if coming in a pack and when lacking form they can devour an entire base by simply being there. That said, their forms (units) do have a lot of advantages such as range, ability to target airplanes and pure damage. The goo has no structures, they are a fluid faction in every meaning of the word.  The Beta are most normal of the factions, specifically said by the Devs to be intentionally so for new players to get used to the game, but they are still very strong and definitively a force to be reckoned with. Their elite unit is a walking production facility that sends out miniature nuclear bombs and is able to attack any close-range enemies by having units mounted ontop of it. This is one of the big strengths of the Beta, some of your units can mount walls and the elite unit, allowing you to create a strong permimiter that is very hard to break through. If you then decide to go on the offensive, the elite unit will help you take down most resistance, having what is probably the strongest of the elite units in the game.  As for the campaign, it is very well made, although, it is a bit short, allowing you to get used to each of the factions while also deliviring a great story that they have confirmed will be expanded. Note: It will come through DLC.  Now, on a more negative note, while humans are strong, they often feel unflexible as you might not be able to expand anywhere due to it not always going so well building uphil and some areas are just blocked off for building. For the Beta, that just means you place it somewhere else, for humans, it means stop.  Also, the game, at least so far, allows for only up to 4 players, meaning you can't even have a 3v3 with one of each faction on each side.

First off, this is a quality game. It is well made, great cinematics, high quality graphics (although the scenes a bit on the dark side) - yes worth the $49 release price IMO. I have now spent about 9 hrs playing and still working things out. It is not complicated, just an initiial learning curve of where and how to build structures, do upgrades, keep resources flowing etc. There is ingame help but I found it to be hints rather than a hand holding guide which I needed when i started playing.   There are 3 factions to learn to play- each quite different,  Like other RTS games the idea is to build up a base/bases and pump out fighting units and destroy the enemy. You only need to collect one type of resource. You can have up to 200 units.  Technically the game plays very smooth and well on the main, i have had the game crash once when I was right clicking madly.  Is it fun? Well yes, I am enjoying the campaign I have played so far. The campaign consists of 15 missions- 5 for each of the 3 factions so plenty of opportunnity to learn all aspects of the game.  The skirmish mode seems a bit limited as there are only 8 options of maps which include number of players each map.  I have not played the MulitPlayyer as yet, due to none of my friends having this game, so cannot comment there.  Nothing can beat my AoM/AoE games but I did enjoy the slightly different style of game here and glad I bought it. If you enjoy space RTS games this is a nice one. 8/10

- The custscenes and story are awesome, the music is awesome, the graphics are good, and the gameplay is fun. - There is an innovative and awesome never seen before faction (the goo) with orchestra/dubsteb music.  Why are you still reading this boring stuff, buy the game!   If you like the classic RTS games, I don't think this can dissappoint you.

(Review update) - Almost a year after this game has been released the balance of the game is still in a bad shape, maps for competitive 1vs1 arent balanced at all, and the factions are as unbalanced as they were in release date, it almost made me update this review and not recommend the game but i still think it can get better.  If this game had faster updates and better developer communication with the community it could have been one of the best RTS`s out there.  Multiplayer: After playing 334 hours and ranking high on the 1v1 leaderboard im totally jaded with this game. Its not a game you should buy hoping for a lasting multiplayer experience, at least not with what the game offers currently.  Single player: The campaign itself is decent with cool cutscenes and a nice lore surrounding the factions, however i wouldnt recommend you buying this game solely on the single player experience, as the campaign itself is not long enough or that interesting compared to the price your paying.  Final opinion; So why do i recommend this game, its a decent game with a cool art and functional gameplay that has the potencial to get better if the developers put their dedication back into the game. But as things stands the game is sort of in limbo waiting for the developers get their act together. I will still recommend it because it has potential that`s the main thing to look for in this game.  So buy it if you wanna support the developers or just want to play a short singleplayer campaign if you are bored. Dont buy it if you want a solid and competitive multiplayer experience.
Westwood is back.   Nuf said.

This is an amazing game. One of the best new RTS games to come out since the Dawn of War series. Incredibly well made; the production values are top-notch. The voice acting, the graphics, the models, and the sound are all incredibly well done. The writing is very solid - telling a familiar sci-fi cautionary tale with an excellent twist.  The gameplay is smooth and well thought out. The only complaint I can recall is that the mini-map isn't as full-featured as I expect from a modern RTS. You can't seem to (or at least, I never could) click on the mimi-map to instantly move your camera to that location. But these misses were minor, few, and far between.  By far my favorite part of the game was the titular faction. The Grey Goo is the most innovative RTS concept I've ever seen. I dare say that they perform the 'Zerg motif' better than the Zerg do - and before you declare me a blasphemer, let me explain. Part of the Zerg flavor was always that they arrive at a planet. murder a bunch of living things, and then use that biomass to increase their own numbers. Sort of like a sci-fi version of a necromancer: your fallen enemies increase your strength.  And that was awesome. But that flavor rarely found its way into the mechanics, really. Sure, you could infest a Terran HQ to produce an infested marine. But that was it. For the vast majority of the time, you harvested crystals and vespene, just like everyone else. And you spawned units out of buildings (albeit gooey buildings) just like everyone else. Not a lot of the 'murdering for biomass' flavor in there.  But the Grey Goo take that concept to its logical conclusion in the mechanics. You have only one production 'building' - the mother goo. It can roam around looking for suitable mass to absorb, but it is also a dangerous unit in its own right. It can traverse any terrain, and it can occupy the same space as enemy units and buildings, damaging them and healing itself while it does so. And its health is the only resource the goo needs. It spends goo (its health) to spawn specialized constructions. Mechanisms made from goo that perform specialized tasks (like murdering things from far away). Then, once the murdering is done, the enemy becomes goo and heals the mother goo. It's a perfect implementation of the 'murdering for mass' flavor that the Zerg made us fall in love with.  But the Grey Goo is just one part of this game that makes it so excellent.  All in all, a highly recommended game.
A very solid, old school rts, that plays closer to Command and Conquer than Starcraft. Other than some fps and balance issues which will likely be fixed, the best rts I've played in a long time.

I did not play this game's multiplayer - as a caveat. The single player met my expectations for a fun storytelling experience with a challenging RTS campaign. It didn't stick out, but it was definitely worth my time and money.

Petroglyph delivers yet again. A game as fun as universe at war yet not as buggy.  The three race dynamic is one that has been in use since Starcraft put it on the map and this game does it justice. Each of the factions has a unique infrastructure and units that make for wildly different strategies when played. There is a single player campaign that involves cut scenes and voice acting which has a high production quality. SP and MP will give plenty of value out of this game.  At times there seems to be a balance issue but that may be just my perception with only 10+ hours into the game thus far.  The interface could use some improvement in some places, but overall you feel in complete control of your forces and are not limited by interface restraints as you are in some of the other RTSes that I have played lately.  Keep it coming Petro.  UPDATE #1: Petro, why only 4 players? We need bigger maps and bigger battles.

Good old style RTS. Having played hundreds of hours of Starcraft 2, I can say that this game is still good. Its slower than Starcraft but thats not a bad thing. I think they are totally different. If you like RTS games and loved the old C & C then this is a must.

Its a really good RTS and runs so freakin smooth and what's this you can build a base and use it WHAAAAT?!?! I had a few issues with it running on WIN10 but it was able to fix it by not launching the game from Steam.   I do think the factions are a little unbalanced but I didn't buy it to play MP with random people. So can't comment to much on that side of things sorry.  - Great GFX - Great SFX - Good Story line  - Hard mode can actually be tough at times and the AI (least what I can tell) doesn't seem to cheat to make it 'Tough'.  Very much worth getting this game now while its on sale!!

Played through about 9 missions in the game and a few skirmishes and I have to say I haven't had this much fun in a RTS game since old westwood CnCs and I am loving it! The love is a very strange feeling because everything feels so on point from units' firing sounds, units voice acting, cutscenes, background music (Especially Agile Manuever for human race...soooo goood), to even the explosion from units' destruction...I definitely recommend this game to even those who haven't tried old CnCs. And this game is also worth even if you don't play multiplayer.

Wow, this game is incredible its basically an adrenaline rush in a box...everything about this game shouts quality. I really belive that this game will be one of the most influential RTS games of all time and put it on par wiith the original C+C series. If you love classic RTS then Grey goo is for you Good Job guys
If your a fan of old RTS games like Command & Conquer, then this is a must get. Great Story, beautiful graphics, and solid gameplay.

Cons:  - Overpowered Goo faction - Short campaign - Too much wait time for any multiplayer match  Pros: - Humans have 'alien technology' - New ideas (Ex: Vonn Neuman Probe [Mother Goo]) - New terminology (Ex: Keyholes) - Good campaign - Finally a non-Blizzard made real time strategy game - Mysterious and intriguingly 'Silent Ones' - Sexy dubbing

I've played quite alot of RTS in my time from the good old command and conquer series to starcraft then warcraft, and few others great RTS Classics. I have to say Greygoo is a great addition to the RTS genre's I mean I haven't seen a good RTS since Dawn of War back in 2008. Once I heard about Grey Goo I though what the hell is this! Then after watching videos and actually getting to play the game I loved it. I mean music in the game is made by Frank Klepacki and if you enjoyed all the classic command and conquer music and red alert 1&2 my god he does some good stuff. I do recommend this game to anyone who likes the old feel of an RTS building, expanding and waging war upon your enemies.   The GreyGoo may be a very odd name for an RTS, but actually it fits quite perfectly for the Race the Grey Goo and what I mean by this is the race is very unique from any RTS I've seen the way you can form your units and gathering resources it different, then your Goo can run over everything and when I mean everything I mean EVERYTHING!!!! it insane.
A Paladin’s Review: Grey Goo. I Review, So That Others May Play Good Games.
A lot like the old C&C games. If you like the old 90s style RTS, then definitely try this out.
Great RTS, but needs a little more polish, especially performance-wise.  To ammend my previous statement: The game stopped crashing on me after 2 weeks. No idea why.

While this genre is now often called the grandpappy of MOBAs and Tower Defense games in this day and age, I'm still an avid fan of RTSs and Grey Goo does not disappoint! It takes many of the best elements from the C&C series and incorporates some progressive new ideas of it's own!   - Single player is incredibly well polished, with great cutscenes, although the story itself leaves something to be desired.   - The QWERTY hotkey-bar setup takes a little while to get used to but is generally much more user friendly than other RTS hotkey configurations like SC and AoE.   - The foliage cover mechanic is a fun twist to traditional cloaking.   - So far balancing between the three factions looks solid, but I haven't played that many multiplayer games yet so we'll have to wait and see if it still feels right after that.   - I enjoy having the resource rate meter on the top right, like Supereme Commander and other games in that vein vs. just a straight up resource count.   - The multiplayer games I've played with my friends so far have been action packed from the get-go. Even with 2 factions having walls, turtling doesn't seem to work as a valid strategy for too long.   - The unit upgrades in the game are more strategic than, 'This just makes my units beefier,' like SC2 where you pretty much have to get some upgrades without thinking too hard about them.   - The Goo is probably the most unique faction I have EVER played in any RTS game. It will be a lot of fun to master!   My only major gripe with this game is that the multiplayer scene looks a little scant so far. More people who love RTSs (of which there may not be many) please buy this game so I can play with yo'll!!! :D

Game reminds me more of Starcraft than Red Alert series.  But hey, I don't mind, Grey Goo I would say is one of the best RTS games released in the past decade.  If there were more RTS games that were coming out which weren't absolutely a complete waste of time, then I should think Grey Goo might still be up there on my top five list. Because it's really sublime. Good soundtrack, good gameplay, all the modern conveniences of a modern RTS (which I appreciate).  Ordering your units around just feels smooth. Unlike some other games, Grey Goo just feels uncluttered and simplistic. I love it. The shortcut keys to quick select units and buildings makes one feel like a pianist, and I love that too. I also like that, it seems to me, the tips on the loading screens are actually useful for once. And that's awesome.  The Grey Goo faction is also pretty neat.  Also, I can't stop saying Grey Goo for some reason. It's a name that really rolls off the tongue. Bonus points for that.  In short, it's an RTS. You like RTS? Get this game. If not? Don't bother. I mean, obviously don't bother, you'll never have fun if it's not your thing. But yeah. Game is good.

Decent RTS but it doesn't really add anything new. I made it through the first 3 campaign missions and wanted to quit because of how boring it was but it really picked up after that so I'm glad I kept playing. Overall the story is good, the factions are different enough to be interesting, and the cutscenes add a lot of atmosphere. Gameplay is solid but overall the game is nothing to write home about.   I'd definitely recommend getting it on a sale and playing through the singleplayer campaign. I'd also be a lot more interested in the sequel they're setting up if they made the campaign a lot longer and really expanded on the story, unit rosters, etc.
This is the first rts in the past few years besides starcraft 2 ive truly enjoyed. the factions have variety but build in similer patterns so its easy to pick up. the champign is pretty damn fun
I would rate this game 10/10 if i can. Includes goo that you can change the colors of. This game is the future. Also directed by Michael Bay

I won't focus too much on the raw gameplay mechanics other than that I find them quite nice and while the amount of units is quite small (I'm not certain if they're considering on developing this aspect of the game further of it the game is 'complete') I enjoyed Grey Goo as a very polished RTS experience. The base-building and unit-building might have been a bit more expansive with more units and buildings to select from, but otherwise I liked what the game had on offer gameplay-wise.   Apart from the raw gameplay, I think the reason why I'm writing this at all is because I love the game's story, atmosphere, graphics and soundtrack so much. I admit, I'm not the most competitive RTS fan, but I can't get enough of listening to Frank Klepacki's (He's a big name when it comes to game composers, I believe) soundtrack for this game and contemplating the game's different factions and characters.  I have probably spent 3-4x more time in listening to the soundtrack and thinking of the game world than I have playing the actual game. The humans in Grey Goo are so interesting with how, in Ecosystem 09 at least, the humans are small in numbers and one single human settlement is both managed and developed by a single human scientist.  The graphics in Grey Goo are spectacular and head over heels above the graphics of the other RTS games I've played.   In all honesty I'd like the idea of having the creative design in Grey Goo combined with a more 'sandboxable' experience such as a city builder or a turn-based tactics game. The sci-fi lore, art design and soundtrack are just to good!

A solid RTS, we havent had anything like it for a while now and im glad it was decided we needed a RTS again. It has been far too long since the last RTS hit the shelves. now there are a few things i really enjoyed about it, The Campaign was fun every mission started and ended with a sweet CGI Scene. i like the factions in general that all have a fairly different playstyle and feel to em, the Maps all looked alien and intresting, with a silly alien Moose standing attop some cliffs moosing it up, The AI felt Fairly Challenging,and there are EPIC units as the game calls it they added allot to the game itself albeit abit overpowered every faction has one and it is fun to see two epic Units Duke it out whilst that Alien Moose is Moosing it up.  Also on a SideNote The Ui is wonderfull.   it felt very polished and its a good title in general it felt like a fun C&C experience. Just forget that last C&C but we dont even count that one do we now.  9/10 Boosh.

The game is a good classic RTS. Nothnig completely innovative, but the game itself is well polished, the races are interesting, it is graphically stunning and gives an overall good satisfaction. If I were to improve anything, it would probably be the AI. Definitely worth getting and playing if you are into the RTS genra.
really quite good as of March 2016. Highly recommended for anyone who enjoyed RA2
It was GOOd.
Fun RTS game that brings back the old C&C Westwood feeling. Good for atleast 12 hours of single player campain.

Honestly, it's a really fun game that's receiving a hell of a lot of support from the developers.   You have so many AAA titles come out from EA, Ubisoft, ect that get little to no support. They ship out a broken game, ask for money for a bunch of content that should have already been in the game, and then leave you with a broken product you had a lot of hope for that crashed and burned after a few months.   Grey Goo had a rough release, but the developers have been continuing to create an awesome gaming experience. They promote tournaments, regularly communicate with the community and keep us in the know of future development.   Thanks for the hard work and keep it up guys!
Excellent Game  My only complaint is the LLOOOOOOONNNNGGGG LOOOOOAAADDDD Times. I have a pretty hefty rig and it seemed to take almost 4 minutes from launching the game from Library to Mission start.
Nice story line!
Fun to play over a free weekend. Wasn't convinced to buy it, even on sale.
A throw back to original RTS like C&C, personaly I love C&C games so this game is great to me. But if your a huge starcraft fan you might not like this game, it might not be for you.
A surprisingly enjoyable old school RTS game. I expect I'll be playing it off and on for months to come. Definitely worth the $20 I paid for it.

I'm only an hour into this game, and as we all know the RTS community tends to look for games with a lot of staying power. Rather than try and talk through every single bit and piece of the game I'm going to give my first impressions, then later on I'll try and throw something more complete up.  First things first: it's gorgeous. The cutscenes, the units, the buildings, everything feels really solid. I will say that my computer chugged a bit on the menu and at the beginning of each cutscene, but my computer (while pretty nice) isn't top of the line. Specs at the bottom if anyone cares. Weirdly enough the actual gameplay doesn't seem to have any slowdowns at all, so I'm wondering if it's just some minor glitch that'll be patched out.  Next up: it's fun! Most of the gameplay is pretty intuitive, the units respond in fairly interesting ways, and in general the game feels like a competent studio worked on it. The only real issue I had as the Beta in the campaign was a mild misunderstanding of the hub system, and if I'm being honest that's probably more down to me being oblivious than anything.  I haven't tried multiplayer at all as yet (waiting on a couple of friends to pick it up), but the gameplay seems like it would translate really easily and well to multiplayer.  The tutorial section of the campaign does a good job of explaining things, and the fact that the tooltips are visible without being overwhelming or intrusive was really nice.  Apparently there's a map editor, and I can hardly wait to start tinkering around with that!  Apparently a fair number of the people in the developer came out of Westwood, and I can only say hurrah to that! I loved me some Red Alert back before the black hole known as EA destroyed them and it's good to see that they seem to be back in business!   One thing I wish they'd bring back is the faction system that existed in Emperor: Battle for Dune. The faction/subfaction choices added a lot of spice to that game, though the overall game sadly doesn't really hold up these days.  PC specs:  CPU: AMD Phenom II 1100t black x6 (running @ 3.3 Ghz) Memory: 8gb 1600 hz RAM GPU: Nvidia GTX 760 (EVGA card)  My hard drive is pretty much garbage, but that just means slightly longer load times.

Great game in a long stagnant and devolved RTS genre. Fantastic presentation of story, can't believe the qualityof facial animations and cutscenes. Great C&C type mechanics. Each race is very unique.  TLDR; If you like C&C RTS mechanics and Sci-fi RTS, buy this.

This game reminds you why you started playing rts games in the first place. I've only just started but the feel of this game has command and conquer all over it! If that sounds like something you can get behind, then don't think and just buy!
This game is a brillant fix for all those desiring a great RTS. The races are defined, each have their own technique to win and are fun to play. The campain is a bit short but very satifying.

Here's the thing, I like RTs and am a hardcore fan, but I don't like to go pro online, or anything like that as I never like online systems, and the same will be with this game, so I play skrimish, campaign and with friends, but STILL there are major problems I see.   Cons-  1. The Humans- The humans are more for turtling, but you can't build beyond your starting position most of the time because conduits can't go over any terrain basically. So supply lines get huge and you must divert your forces to protect the miners. The Beta and Goo don't have this problem, and THIS IS MAJOR!!!! because resources run out which pisses me off a little. Just make it either slow regeneration or less income once it reaches the bottom don't remove it all together.   2. Unit Cap- I don't want a game very similar to starcraft. I want a game like CnC with as many units as the computer can take, massive.... MASSIVE battles(also like many huge RTS games) having a unit cap takes away from that. It makes the game more limited.   3. Player Count- 4.....really? Only 4? From what I've seen 4 players is it which at that point I'm like, 'LAME!'  4. Campaign gameplay- Well if you've played it, most people will probably be like c'mon wanna play the Goo campaign. Well 15 missions essentially and 90% of them are kill the enemy. there are at most 3 that aren't 'kill the enemy'. It's fine if it's like that but maybe have cool assaults or epic maps, nah. There are never more than 3 more commanders on the field. You only get an ally for one mission(haven't 100% the goo yet as I need a brake from 'KILL THE ENEMY!') and that mission is kill the enemy. Not hold off and distract long enough to detonate the bomb(sorry spoilers) just kill the enemy.   There are probably other problems but before I stop.   5. Player Content- ok love it how they support the community....steam workshop? Um can you mod this for more unit cap or stuff like that?(You can but the config is a .MEG file...REALLY?!) They do support it but they shouldn't rely on people to make cooler maps to add to their collections. There is only like 7 maps...only 7 and most of them are very similar. I REALLY HOPE that the community through mods if they can and maps make this game much better. If they can make unlimited unit cap and balance the races more to cope with that. Make it so that the player count is 8 or above for better play(if they can) etc...  Pros...Sorry fror bashing on a game but people need to understand from a casual gamer what it is like playing a game and what you should get, but here are the pros.   Camapign Cutscenes- Beautiful and stay with the story. They can immerse you in the universe fairly quickly but sadly what it seems like you're doing from the cutscenes doesn't happen in the gameplay half the time.   Factions- Now I know I bashed on the humans but the factions are unique, especially the Goo. If they kill something they use the matter to grow and reporudce more quickly. The regular goo can quickly consume enemies that are alone or in small groups and can flee up terrain once done. owever to limit their OPness on the ground they get no air. Sadly the Goo and Humans are very similar to Earth's 2160 counterparts.   Epics- Now the epics are essentially the Titans of Warhammer. They are ultimate units and deserve to be for taking up 70 unit cap. However each is unique to the faction. The humans sport a collosal humanoid robot with a large beam that seeps and kills most units in it's path. The purger for the Goo is the ultimate evolution and can attack from range while also getting close and absorbing the enemies through a potent (I guess melee attack). The Beta get a mobile fortress which can produce units and house them for close range defense.   Learning Curve- Factions are easy to learn but definitely hard to master.   Now I know it looks like I dislike this game, I don't it's just I expect better now. I mean to put a unit cap and then express how the game would run smoothlymakes me say 'really? maybe the game runs smoothly not because of the servers but the unit cap?' Also the factions still need work even though polish was done some very clear things should be fixed. like Humans and Beta should be able to build more command centrs(Goo can.....and humans need it to continue to expand). This game is worth the money but not more worth it and that makes me sad. Until player content streams in this game is not that great to me. Any RTS fans wanting something new though go ahead and try it, you'll get your money's worth.   Rating: 7/10 (Not bad, but not great either).

8.5/10  Although I have some good memory with SC1 and C&C red alert2 when I was a teen, I'm not much a RTS fan after I found out that this genre push its direction toward competitive play and fast-click fast reaction.  But sometimes I still have some urge to play as a commander of an army after I've watched a movie like the Lord of the Ring or Starship Troopers, that's why I still have been trying to search for an RTS game which does not required me to have light speed reaction, then I heard about Grey Goo and finally have a chance to try it.  here's what I think about this game  Pros - slow paced, this game doesn't forced you to have light speed reaction and apm, but still faster than Sins of a Solar Empire. It's a very good time killer if you have 1 hour before you need to do something else, and have no idea what to play in your Steam library. - no micromanagement like activating units' skill, it's more about units position and type - EXCELLENT game design, it has a very fun and unique resource management and base building mechanic. Building base and army feel less chore than classic RTS, and more easy because there's automation for building units and base - great graphic. It bring me back some memory of SC1, but I wish units could have more texture detail  Cons  - only 3 factions with 9-11 unit types per factions, I wish it'll go the same direction as DOW instead of SC2, DOW is not as balance as SC2 but people still love the game because it fulfill their multi-factions war fantasy - a wall of core-gamer and competitive gamer bashing suggestions and ideas from casual gamer. That's why there's not much hope for new units and new factions  - Human units design looks too simple....it's just some random floating objects with gun for me

I personally enjoy playing this game a lot more than sc2 now. While the units can be a little simplistic, the game itself is amazing now and actually has a pretty vigorous multiplayer scene and population. This game has a come a long way over the last few months and, at this point, it is absolutely worth a purchase.

Fun RTS with fun and unique factions. The Goo faction is by far my favourite and is actually what I've always dreamed Starcraft's Zerg would be. The campaign is quite short and I'm still not sure if the ending actually is the ending, but in my opinion it's more fun than C&C has been in years.
Don't let people tell you it's not skill-based or micro-intensive enough. Plenty of room for skill to show through and the 3 factions are all fun and diverse.
Excellent RTS game! Love the Goo faction; they are unlike anything I've seen before!
Must have RTS. Also, if you are looking for a new game/genre to play, this is a must have! A lot of fun!

Good old base building RTS with decently difficult AI and CGI that is just incredible. Only issue with the game is that if you alt-tab, or any notification takes you to windows the game pretty much crashes. Maybe not worth that full price, but a great game none the less.

I'll get my only con out of the way first. The name Grey Goo actually had me question paying 50 dollars for a new game. I know what the name refers to, but I really feel that with all the other spectacular work put toward the game, a better name could have been agreed upon.   Onto why I feel like writing a review. This game is gorgeous. Even the character designs during the cutscenes look great. The world you play in looks alive. And a cool cover system is in place by having overhead forest canopy that blocks you from enemy sight so you can spring an ambush.   Playstyle is very similar to Command & Conquer and Warcraft 3. Easy to learn but difficult to master. At least from my experience. Other more proficient RTS gamers may find the game too easy. But I do recommend this game to all levels of players.   If you have the money to spend on a new title, it would be well spent on this game. I wish the name was different, in fact I passed over the game at first based on the name alone. I'm happy that I gave it a second look.
Nice old school gameplay, amazing singleplayer and an eye pleasing title with pretty neat optimisation.   you really should give it a try.

Edit:  I'm about a third of the way through the campaign (normal difficulty) and still really enjoying the game. CGI, Story, gameplay, music, etc. all top notch.

If your looking for a solid all round classic style RTS, this is the game or you. Very easy to pick-up and learn or new to the genre players, and right at home for veterans. while retaining the classic styling of RTS games, it adds a new unique faction to the game. only limited by lack of unit types and few maps, I see no reason this game shouldn't make main stream.  pros:  -solid RTS with easy to learn gameplay -good graphics -campain for all 3 factions -voiced campains -epic units add a game changing force -WALLS!!  cons: -lack of units -favors swarm tactics (could be pro if you like that) -lacks unit formation and spacing (something i like) -lacks the ability to set unit condition (agressive, defensive, passive)

Petroglyph promise to consumers slow paced action game that have traditional RTS formula like CNC, great narrative story and campaign, competitve match making multiplayer, well balanced 3 faction, ROCK PAPER SHOTGUN formula. I really loved this genre game, but still it have minor bug and another thing that should be improve in future update and optimizing the core game to make sure great replayability and great experience toward gamers out there (i play this game on laptop that use obselete GPU nvidia gt 525m but still can play it and i had experience low FPS when there was so many many many many many unit >.< )   WHAT I LIKE ABOUT THIS GAME?  + It have 3 distinct faction that require player to play it with different style + slow paced, no more APM keyboard of warrior of destruction of speed of 1000 light years of spamming button that will blow your mind to micro each one of your unit until you forget about macroing your own base to train unit, expand base, build base (i think whose play starcarft 2 with 100 apm will find this game very modest and have more time to think strategy carefully) + Excellent campaign with 15 mission overall, but very tricky mission 5 and mission 15 that will consume your much time even in normal mode, I failed many time in order to attempt this both mission. But still this campaign will be EPIC toward the end of this game + I like Grey Goo Game unit variation. It have so many potential outcome + User interface is likely distinguish based on the faction characteristic. It is very intuitive and easy remember like MOBA QWER keyboard style + Best Auto macro unit training/ autoproduction (you don't require to repeat many times to train units. it have automatic queue-cycle that will repeat it self until you decide to stop its production. Sitback and enjoy but don't forget to rally point) + This game is easy to learn and hard to master. very depth strategy in this game require you to know each unit, there will be no useless unit as each unit have its own benefit and its own capabiltiy. Each unit also have very unique attribute and modest upgrade to make sure the game will be fun to play + Upgrade system is trully relevant and well balance. It is very crucial to upgrade your own army to counter enemy strategy. I found each of faction's upgrade are really efficient to counter enemy strategy. + modable game. Damn sure this game will have good modding to extend its replayability in future + nostalgia of CNC when i was child + good music, my fav soundtrack is 'agile maneuvers'. Great job Frank Klepacki (i got it free) + <spoiler> my speculation of this game :   fourth faction is 'the silent ones' according to morra/beta. the goo faction is good guy here that will defend sentient like human from extinct due to the silents one invasion   + (will add more in future)   WHAT I DISLIKE ABOUT THIS GAME?  + very few map to play + please improve matchmaking + please make sequel fast + no very super hard AI, after couple of game i found hard AI of 3 faction is rather easy and it have same strategy every each time I play + minor bug occur occasionally but it don't appear to distract gameplay (lucky me for having zero crash, I am just using nvidia gt 525m) + no matchmaking player coop versus ai (2 vs 2) + i hope in future there will be 8 player maximum to play + please make round cycle path Guard command (button G) + unit that hold position still force move if collide/intersect with other unit's pathfinding movement. I don't want relocate again my unit and then hold postion again. Waste of time to focus on this matter. + no passive stance behaviour, in other RTS games unit can have 3 or more stance which is passive, hold postion, aggrasive + no replay like starcraft 2 (that is really demerit points!) + (later i will update what I dislike about this game, it is so hard to notice fault within this game)   MY FIRST EXPERIENCE PLAY MULTIPLAYER (UNRANKED) :  I choose beta as primary faction, my enemy is human and we fight unraked match making. We played Stalker's Rise map and my position was west and my opponent was east. I did early scout and find out my enemy is focusing in economy and rushing to second and third refinery, I finished my second refinery after build small factory, I follow my intuition by trains commando to scout every potential of resources that opponent may place its extractor. This time, i have advantage of army while my opponent have advantage of resources and hard base defense (i scout his base again). I think carefully and made decision to favor more on offensive path than defense. few minute later, I have an adequate army to raid his base but as i scout then, opponent base is likely hard to breach. In meantime I did discover enemy's 5 extractor in total while I only have 3 extractor. That time I only have two choice whether to raid his base or harass his economy. So, I decide to harass his economy by destroying his undefend extractor with all my army. Lucky me, my opponent just retaliate with only quarter population army while not having chance to fight back with my half maximum population army. I managed to destroy his southeast and northeast extractor. While Harassing his economy I hastenly build Hand of Ruk (HOR) Epic Unit. After 5 min, I brought my HOR to near his place for penetrate his strong defense with HOR long range nuke. Guess what, my enemy also finished training alpha. My nuke land first at alpha but it barely reduce alpha hitpoint, i got panic and send all my unit to attack his alpha and then his alpha overwhelm my army within second. So I extend my vision with stratus and eject beacon to enemy headquarter, I give up to fight head on with his alpha directly so I change my focus to his headquarter. I command HOR to attack his headquater(HQ) while running from his alpha (circulate his cliff base). I managed to destroy his HQ inside his base, his alpha stop chasing me and directly go to my base. I managed to destroy his alpha with HOR using hit n run strategy. And what left is destroy all his remaining structure. My first win unranked matchmaking.   MY CONCLUSION ABOUT THIS GAME :   This game have a big potential to expand and become more polish infuture. Don't get me wrong this game have more merit than demerit. It have weakness and stregth. For me this game is perfectly fine and it need more content to play such as arcade mode feature based on starcraft 2. I highly reccomended to play this game for all who suck at APM and noob like me. This game is likely target to the customer whose want slow paced action casual gameplay. I give 9/10 Mark

+ Old school RTS with a twist + Nice CG in cutscenes + Campaign is challenging  + Some unique mechanics, especially the Goo + Music  - Lack of micro and poor unit interaction (units feels unresponsive due to turn rate) - Combine the slow turn rate with slow movement speed units, everything feels VERY slow. - Terrible Bot for skirmish - Units are more or less same spread across different race (other than Goo) - Unit design is not very distinctive, makes it hard to see in bush especially. - Some Lag (most likely due to engine limitation) - NO REPLAY   Who is it for: If you enjoy watching groups of units attacking eachother and doesn't want to bother too much with micro. Enjoys Traditional C&C RTS.  Who should stay away: Looking for a fast paced, action packed multi tasking RTS game Limited money  6.5/10

A pretty solid throwback to CnC style RTS - with the addition of a pop cap, and Dawn of War style focus on resource capturing in the field (though not as aggressive as DoW's)  Invariable similarities will be drawn to other RTSes (Zerg = Goo, Protoss = Human etc etc) but the game's factions are not a direct lift off other IPs and are pretty unique vs. each other and in the absolute as well. This is a solid, very traditional RTS that's an obvious throwback to the better Command & Conquer titles (especially C&C 3). I haven't tried multiplayer (I suspect not many people are playing), but the campaigns are varied, fun, and interesting.  To be honest, I have no idea why the reviews are so mixed. Grey Goo doesn't bring much new to the genre, but has some great qualities. Its C&C-style large-scale top-down strategy emphasis (as opposed to Blizzard style bottom-up micromanagement hell) makes the game fun for casual to moderately serious RTS players. 'Serious' RTS players who measure their success in APM might be disappointed, but they will also be missing out on a great game.  The storyline and characters are engaging and memorable enough, with the cutscene character models being some of the most realistic seen in a game of any genre.  The lack of a robust AI is a problem, but not one that brings the game down. It is a pity, because it stops challenging the player fairly early in the game, but in general RTS AI has never been strong, and we should not expect it.   The very small number of maps means that play outside of the campaign can become dull and repetitive more quickly than it ought to, and the developers should address this by producing a number of them in the future, perhaps with the planned expansion.
Very nice game, great potential.  7/10

I will begin with things that bother me: -VERY performance intensive, 40 frames solo, 10 frames in multiplayer. -If you only play Red Alert or the Tiberium games, Grey Goo is unintuitive. -It's very starcrafty in the sense that you need building attatchments to build special units -there are no thumbnail illustrations for the unit building buttons and profiles, instead you have these starcraft-like schematics that I guess show a detailed 3d image of the unit body health.  -The tutorial is a ingame wiki page with gifs - it's weird but it's useful. You will listen to the menu theme infinitely while you read the wiki tutotial pages. It gets repetitive :( -Units look too similar. -The UI and font are very small especially if you are on a laptop.  -The UI is dota/LoL based in the sense that QWERT are shortcuts for buildings and units. -Until you set up the game to fit your pc/laptop specs the game will load a minimum of 2 minutes before every match. -No tactical consumables such as: air strike, paratroopers, map reveal, etc.  Things I am no sure how I feel about: *There is a fixed population cap *floating resource cap *Game is very serious *Beta are butt ugly  Things I enjoy: +Made by the Westwood guys +Frank made the OST +Epic units are hard to make +Factions are more diverse than RA3 and CnC4 +Tech upgrades limits your playstyle  In conclusion: It's not as flashy as Red Alert3 or Tiberium Wars. Maybe if I played strategy games other than Red Alert2/3 and Tiberium Wars/Kane's Wrath, I would say that the game has a high skill ceiling. I wish it wasn't so demanding.

I rated it a Yes only for 1 reason its not a bad game...but it would be one of the best of the best if the community was allowed/given tools to make it their own. I dont write reviews much but there is a diamond in the rough if the devs could see the potential.  Slow paced RTS, computer on easy will knok on your front door before your base gets structured enough to defend yourself (like a zerg rush but with guns) once you kill 1 there will be another to follow within 5 to 10 sec.   Not an intuitave game and the base structure is simplistic which leavs me the feeling that I only have a few options making a skirmish feel like a pre written war novel...long, painful and everyone dies.  Pros; Great grapics Creative races Story mode (Did'nt get enough time to explore it much) Fluid framerate (even at 4x superscale)  Cons: Slow inital base developement  Weak base (lowest rung) fighters that take way to long to build/create. In SC a zerg rush can be stopped by marines or protoss infantry if played correctly   Game Mechanics - for being a simple tree structure It was too difficult to well develope your army (balancing of time/resources required)  Balancing - While the idea was creative and interesting It really makes the impression that the focus was put into the story rather than the skirmishes. If you want a RTS to live forever (like SC original) make the multiplayer aspect shine. No one plays the story for years and years. if this game was built around a multiplayer community that could mod and contribute to the final product then even with the flaws mentioned above it would go toe to toe with the best of the best because the gamers would be driving the game aspects not just reading it page after painful page.  Bottom Line:  I won't pay for it untill it gets a community driven feel. cheapen and hasten lowest rung fighters to allow for epic infantry battles that start early and persist untill you develope higher teir fighters (cost of lowest teir should be less than 1/2 that of the next highest). Simple base structures should be quicker and use less resources to make. bigger maps with community developed maps supported. dedicated customizeable servers with an ingame browser would get the community to a religious following.  I think it can be great but that will depend on the devs ability to let go a bit.

Would I recommend this game to people? Yes. Would I Recommend it to Timmy the 8 year old thats played Starcraft and think all strategy games are the same? NO. This game was by no definition; EASY. This game is an RTS that is beautifully animated. If you like the old Warcraft III, The Frozen Throne, Star Craft and Civilization, You're gonna love this game. The plot is quite intresting with diffrent short cinematic scenes appearing as you progress through a level and it is fully voice acted as well. It has very intresting game mechanics similar to Dota 2 and Leugue of Legends where the player can spot enemy forces on elevated ground and can set up an ambush by hiding in certain forests.   Although it is a good game it still has some flaws. It is not very polished and can cause random crashes if you Alt+Tab too much. The balancing of the races is too much in favour of the Beta and the Goo. The humans are just really weak. Finaly, the game takes a long, long time to load. it differs from pc to pc but in my experience with all graohics settings on lowest, it takes about 7 minutes to load.....Thats a long time....  I really reccomend you go check it out anyways. It is a good, solid game and I hope the will patch up and polish out their flaws in later updates and patches.

Here's the deal... I really like this game. It's rare for a developer to not only make an RTS, but also a good story with it. Full of likeable characters, a great soundtrack and fun gameplay.  Some possible spoilers below.  Pros:  1.) Solid, varied gameplay. All 3 sides are very different. Humanity, The Beta, and the Goo. 2.) The Story is well thought out, with bits of backstory that really add to the experience. It leave me wanting more. I really hope there will be a sequel. 3.) Mutliplayer is fun and fast paced. Not for people who want to turtle or play defensive games however. Expect most matches to end within 30-45 minutes, or possibly faster. 4.) It's an RTS in an era that has forgotten this once great genre. I love supporting anyone willing to make a AAA RTS.  It's not without it's issues however. The Multiplayer is very limited, just 1v1 or 2v2. The reason for this given by the developer is performance, which I can believe. However, I'd rather the developer just leave multiplayer open for the future, when more players have hardware capable of running the game well. I believe this is the chief reason for the game not being more successful than it is.  Cons:   1.) Only 1v1 or 2v2. This limits the appeal of the multiplayer greatly. I really hope the dev opens up 3v3 and 4v4. 2.) Micromanagement can be excessive. This is really a problem with most RTS games however. 3.) Late game is dominated by high end units, like Epic units and heavy tank units. This tends to also be a weakness in RTS games. I would like to see tech 1 units stay useful in late game. 4.) Story ends on a cliffhanger... I'm afraid that I won't get the whole story if we don't get a sequel.  Overall, I really like this game and want more. It's easily accessible to Starcraft 2 and Command and Conquer fans, and has as enjoyable a story as SC2.  8.5/10. 9/10 if you don't care about 3v3 and 4v4 multiplayer.
A good game. hopefully there is an option to make a game faster. Also more campaign. More unit types.  Humans feel weaker and inflexible than the other two. Weak AI

One of the best RTS have a played in a LONG time. Wonderful production quality, and brilliant gameplay. The only thing that was lacking for me was a full continuity of storyline, though I am told that is resolved with the DLC that is available.

CAMPAIGN While the campaign is not much more than proving ground for your up and coming battles onine it still has it merits. Lush, diverse environments, very well thought out maps, a short story but the landscape tells enough to strech it out, no sloppy excuses to wage war here.  BASE BUILDING Each race has it's own unique building format allowing for a completely dfferent play style in base building, be it dispersed, centralised or deadly mobile baby belching carnage.  UNITS The one down fall this game may have is it's units diversity. Each race can build a max of 200 and although each unit may look different each approach is very similar, you have several sets of upgradable abilities that are revesable / interchangable. In this game no unit has it's own micromanagement bar the epic, it comes down to your ability to control the sway of war not how quick you can bash a spell button.  MAP EDITOR The map editor is second to none, this is where the game really shines. Build the ultimate skirmish map or even deisgn your own campaign with almost no limits. Such a varied and vibrant world, you can even import your own prefabs and textures and dish out a decent set of instructions to your AI factions. though the editor does not come without a few minor bugs., well... just. SAVE OFTEN..lol  MULTIPLAYER As yet i have not dealt with the multiplayer side of things bar the map making. I have heard it was randomly crashing though from what i read grey goo has been fixing/fixed the issue, they run tournaments for cash say $75000 to win? so issues can't be to prolific. The fan base is growing so you should expect more and more to log in for war, at present the online number can be a little low from what i hear.  This game has come from a few of the ppl from Westwood before EA fked it, so it will have some old school feel n appeal for some.  Enjoy!  ( i got it on sale via the free weekend )

I only play multiplayer co-op against the computer, so if you love going against other players, ignore my review.  Very fun game! Campaign is decently long (13 hours to complete), the story is well told, the factions have few units so the differences between them is huge which make it feel far more varried then most other RTS's. You don't have specials to worry about so you can focus on your stratagies rather than just clicking as many times as possible.

Definetly one of the best RTS games out there, graphics are good, campaign is basically a massive multi-faction tutorial and the skirmish mode is equally as satisfying. It's quite simple compared to many others and thats what makes it great. It really is alot like the original starcraft but with a much more interesting campaign and factions that have completely different playstyles. Each faction playes differently than the other, and each faction has many different ways to play within itself, because of having such a vast selection of specialized units available. You can rush with basic infantry all the way to the end of the game if your fast enough, or play the defensive and build mega units that crush everything in their way. The GOO faction really puts a twist on how an RTS can be played and Im glad someone finally changed the genre up.  The default Hotkeys are kind of confusing and there's just too many of them, its' a good idea to play the tutorial missions and then go and re-map the hotkeys that you use the most into one spot on the keyboard.

I give this game a 9/10 at the moment. I have only played a few rounds so far, but the tactics look and feel great, graphics are awesome, and it appears to be a very responsive RTS. I'm very impressed and enjoying this game. I recommend for ANY RTS fans that love sci-fy lore. The cut scenes in between missions are well done and interesting.   VIDEO ISSUES RESOLVED: I had some trouble with huge framerate issues at first. However, after researching on the GreyGoo support page I found some things I could do to fix the problem, such as disabling SLI, etc. I tweaked my Nvidia video card 3D settings to allow the program to control the settings and tweak a couple other settings and now it's working great!! I'm running on a GeForce GTX 860m Asus Laptop and now playing on HIGH graphics/full resolution 1920 settings with no framerate or lag issues.   If you are having these problems and you have a NVIDIA card.. go to your Geforce Control Panel and manage 3D settings. Change your preferred graphics processor to High-Performance NVIDIA processor, and go to the Adjust image settings with preview... and select Let the 3D application decide. I left the Set Physx Configuration to Auto-Select. After making these changes the game worked perfect Good luck and kick some RTS butt!

Let me first say that I *cautiously* recommend this game. What I mean by that is that I *don't* recommend this game to a wide number of people, but I believe there is a subset of players that will enjoy what Grey Goo offers.  Grey Goo is somewhat a return-to-form for some of the former Westwood team (Command and Conquer series), and that's very apparent here. The build, repair, sell systems bring back fond memories for me of eveything from Tiberian sun to RA3. The factions follow a lot of industry standards. Firstly, there's three of them. Second, one is very technologically advanced (ironically the Humans in this case), another is more rough-and-tumble (Beta), and the last is a force of pure destruction seemingly without conscience (Goo). See also: Protoss, Human, Zerg - or the equivalent in most other RTS games. That said, there are distinctions which make all three interesting - and the Goo provide a new sort of challenge because of their mobility. Possibly a challenge which still hasn't been properly balanced, depending on whom you ask.  Performance-wise, Grey Goo (at present) is merely acceptable. A lingering issue since launch relates to stutters and the inevitable slowdown that usually occurs 10 minutes into a match. I'm talking the difference between 90fps at the start and 20fps by the end of a match. This seems to be more an issue in multiplayer/skirmish than it is in the campaign. The devs have promised this will be addressed in the next major patch within a week or two. For reference, I played the game on a GTX 760 with an i5 4690k, but users on both sides of the spectrum from my hardware have confirmed the same issue.  As for the singleplayer, WETA's influence with character design is one of the stronger points. The storyline is certainly serviceable but likely won't surprise too much. Difficulty was recently more-evenly balanced than launch. Previously the game proved quite challenging even on the easiest settings.  The long-short: If you're looking for a new RTS and don't mind the above-listed flaws, Grey Goo is a game from a talented team that may be worth your time. There's a lot of love here, to be certain; it's just too bad it wasn't more fully-realized at launch. If, on the other hand, you're looking for the next competitive RTS, this likely won't fit the bill. The community is small at present - though most are very nice. It's hard to say what (if anything) the devs will do to promote the game going forward, but I'd be very surprised to see it suddenly become an eSports sensation. Still, I enjoyed my 51 hours with Grey Goo.

Just finished the Campaign. Definitely enjoyed the subtle RTS improvements Petroglyph has implemented in Grey Goo. So this is a plus for players like me.   The plot starts to get exciting right around when the Campaign ends, so there is definitely room for some DLC/Expansion to keep things moving along.   Can't wait for the first balance update!

Grey Goo is a very traditional RTS. No hero units or unit leveling of any kind, minimal unit micro-management, a reasonably high unit cap and proper base building. It is also rather slow paced compared to the likes of Starcraft II.  The production values are suprisingly high. Music and audio are great and campaign cutscenes are very impressive. Maps themselves are quite beautiful as well, even if most of the units and buildings look rather bland.  Gameplay itself is very traditional. There's nothing wrong with this really, not every game needs to be super innovative. Especially in a genre which is pretty much dead these days. The game copies the classic Command & Conquer gameplay formula more or less intact.  The game has four playable factions, the Humans, the Beta, the Goo and the Shroud. Humans and beta are very traditional RTS races that play very similarly to each other. The titular Goo, however, are something much more unique.  The Goo don't have a traditional base at all and instead of collecting resources, mother goo units regenerate health while on a resource node. The mother goo can then sacrifice some of its health to create new units. This is certainly the most innovative aspect of the game. Unfortunately this also leads to some tedious micro-management and I wasn't personally a big fan of the playstyle.  The shroud were not part of the original game and were added in a later patch. They only appear as an enemy in a bonus campaign mission and are also available for skirmish and multiplayer games. I didn't end up seeing enough of them to get a good feel of how they play.  For the most part the unit design is quite boring for all factions, both visually and ability-wise. The ultimate Epic units are a lot more exciting, but they take a long time and lot of resources to build and you generally use only one per map.  The user interface is for the most part quite decent and pretty much what you would except in an RTS. All the usual hotkeys are there and the controls work the way you expect them to. It's missing a few of the more advanced features, but overall the UI is decent enough.  The campaign itself is passable but again nothing spectacular. The story is quite forgettable. Surely the titular grey goo (aka runaway self-replicating nanobots) could have been used to tell a more interesting story. Missions themselves are pretty standard fare for the most part, even if some of the missions spice up things a little bit. Personally I found the campaign difficulty surprisingly high. Usually I play single-player RTS games on hard, but after the first few missions I decided to switch to normal. Part of this difficulty does come from bad mission design, however, as a lot of missions have enemy units spawning from thin air.  Personally I find Grey Goo rather hard to recommend unless you are a big RTS fan looking for a new game to play. There's nothing really wrong with the game but despite the high production values it suffers from some bland design and doesn't bring anything new to the genre. Best to wait for a sale or a bundle with this one.  I played through the main campaign on normal and also finished the Emergence DLC mini-campaign. I also played a couple skirmish games against the AI. I don't normally play multiplayer with strangers, so I skipped that part of the game.  The good: - Solid old-school RTS gameplay - Beautiful cut-scenes - Great music by Frank Klepacki (of C&C fame)  The bad: - Visual design of the units and buildings is rather bland - Some issues with unit balance - Some annoying campaign missions - Forgettable story - Goo faction is interesting but ultimately not that fun to play - Map visuals can be somewhat confusing at times and it's hard to tell what's passable terrain and what's not - Very strict line of sight rules are too easy to exploit  The ugly: - Performance could be better - Saving and especially loading take a very long time

While all the media stresses an emphasis on story, decision making and tactics, the campaign is thin and linear.   As for the tactics, each faction is little more than a graphical mod of a very simple core design with one or two unique units. The unit cap and cost of units combine to very much *discourage* building a diverse force with specialized units working to support each other in varied roles and you end up simply building the current faction's unique unit until you hit the unit cap and wiping the map with it. SHORT VERSION: Game's dead, guys...Move on and get something else, Dont buy.   LONG VERSION: A pretty good RTS from some of the veterans of the genre. The campaign is well done with some really nice CGI scenes and a good all-round story, nice visuals and game mechanics overall.   However, we play Real Time Strategy games nowadays for the multiplayer, which Grey Goo has of course.  A shame then, that the multiplayer portion of Grey Goo is now essentially dead. It started out with a player-base of about 2750 people worldwide on launch. The current average player-base at peak times is now around 70.. 'worldwide'.  That combined with some MAJOR issues, like the dev's inability to fix multiplayer lag ( which is probably one of the reasons all of the players left ), The crazy price tag ( I mean, I've got 70 hours on record, and I still think it cost too much ) Like, the only other RTS at that price is Starcraft 2.... obviously not going to get grey goo over a storied well looked after series like starcraft for obvious consumer reasons.  Other things like lack of maps ( More are comming aparently ), No replays ( which is being added, aparently ), bad unit balance (as in with one Race, you can win by just spamming the same 2 Tier 1 units, since AOE just cant handle them anymore after the latest 'balance update' ) bad tech balance, for example free repairing of expensive aircraft, or extra harvestor armour, or extractor armour... the armour thing should be combined, with one choice being something completely different from the armour and aircraft repair, its an obvious choice every time.  I want to love this game so much, but because of the non-existant player-base and some of the more aformentioned issues, I just cant. I mean, the game is a good as dead, the dev's might as well stop updating and make Grey Goo 2 or something.  A sad 'Unable to Recommend' from me.

I picked this up during the summer steam sale and while it does have some nice qualities, overall I feel it is lacking in depth, expected RTS features, and overall seems a bit risk averse to give it staying power. I did have some fun going through some matches, but ultimately don't anticipate this will remain in my library for long. Specifics thoughts:  -Nice keyboard shortcut scheme. You select the building or unit type with QWER+ and then it brings up a new set of choices, again QWER+ and then a final menu. So, if you need a certain unit you very quickly realize you can do EQQ or whatever... but, the game does lack some expected commands. Can't pause at any point or change the game speed, no select all units, couldn't figure out how to bring up FPS, etc.   -Has a neat cover system where you can hide in a forest and fire from it w/o being targeted... but, there's few areas on the maps and they are too large. They should've been more liberal with the placement of cover and included some smaller one-unit areas. Some other games I can recall have done this maybe a bit better.   -The two human/alien races are a bit too similar. Props to them for making the Goo race work very differently, though. I feel they put all their risk in this one race and played the rest of the game too conservatively.   -The units within those races are a bit too similar. For example, it's very obvious in a game like StarCraft how a marine, siege tank, and hellion are different. No questions about strengths and even confusing unit types. In this game, the units tend to run together once in a category. There are a few exceptions, air units and artillery are definitely different, but I found the units overall a bit bland.   -The tech is pretty cool. You have 4 tech choices each with 3 options. Once you commit to an option within those choices (eg, Tech granting Anti-Air unit ground attacks as well) you can't pick the other 2. Was easy enough to manage from the interface and understand what each bonus was. I tended to pick the same bonuses game to game, unsure if that was play style or simply balance problems but would have to play more to know for sure.   -Framerate / slowdowns - Toward the end of a longer game, the game 'stutters' while trying to compensate for what I think is low framerates (can't pull it up to determine, though). Could be network? Hard to say what it was, but I've got a solid connection and a solid i7 w/ GTX 960 and graphics actually mostly turned down.   -Building placement all have to be part of your initial set of root structures (either your HQ or hubs if you're playing Beta). They went for a smaller singular base as a game decision, okay that works. However, it is not elegantly done. Some of the ways attachments work early on (you have to attach a Tank module to a factory to allow you to build tanks) make it easy for new players to make mistakes and build useless modules. In addition, it was a bit buggy when selling structures, I'd sometimes cut power off to half my base. Okay, that's a feature, let me rebuild it to connect power again. Nope. Guess it is a bug, but ran into a few times where visually I should have power but half my buildings wouldn't.   All in all, for a 60% off steam sale this reminded me of the heyday of RTS fifteen years ago where I'd pick up a new game in the summer and nine out of ten times would see it fall flat, just as this one has.
It was ok I guess. Just got a bit tedious.

I regret buying this game.  There are three races, with very different building systems However the units built by them are all the same, so gameplay is largely the same. I mean exactly the same, a light unit, an anti armour unit, a tank, an artililary, an anti air and a couple of aircraft.  Combat is dull, there are no melee units, no fast units. Air get destroyed by anti air, to the point where they are unusable.  The game is slow, units take forever to build and forever to move. Feels like you wait alot.  There is little micro, the simplicity of the units seems to be designed to remove the micro from the game.  Building is clunky (appart from the goo), for some reason things keep needing to be attached to other things. For example, humans have one core base, then every other builing needs to be connected by a pipe to the main base building. The pipe is weak and fustrating to place and should there ever be a gap in the pipe everything downstream stop s working. (you can't place buildings out of LOS). (Note humans can't build a second main base, so good luck building over to the next resource patch, 'enjoy' that frustration)  This is nothing like starcraft, i would say it is closer to total ana. Just slower, with no depth and no fun.

Post-release, the developers completely changed the scope and nature of the game, turning it into an expensive Starcraft clone, after it was advertised to fans as a faithful Westwood-type RTS, with the name of that now defunct studio routinely bandied about. The game released without either observer or replay mode, an incomplete campaign, and just a handful of multiplayer maps; all we were given was developer promises to deliver on these inadequacies. Now, that promised content is only available via DLC.   If it at least had a healthy population, there might be a reason to tell you to get it, but everything about this game says “stay away.” If you already own Starcraft, you've already experienced the gameplay, anyway.

Got this at 50% off which should be the original price, the campaign is short, the game mechanics are clunky as if they this game came out 20 years ago, the game is also really really slowwwww, and considering there are 0 special abilities to use thats just stupid so you basically just A-Click your stuff and watch, you'll spend 10 minutes every game just getting resources to get a decent production going, the units are completely uninspired and there are very few of them, and the ultimate units are way too powerful, and the campaign is insanely short, like 4 missions per faction which goes in a chain starting with the Beta (humanoid aliens), then the humans, then the Goo.   The Goo are also the worst RTS faction i have ever played, they're supposed to be mobile and massing, except imagine having all of your production facilities spread all over the map with no way to rally troops forcing you to click each individual mother goo (production unit) to spawn a small or large blob which then can be transformed into your units, small blob for basic, big blob for more advanced units, and they have 0 aircraft units and every unit is slow as balls.  Beta and Humans are pretty basic designs, Beta have outposts that range from small to large and buildings have to be placed next to them to gain power and function with their main defense being emplacing troops on walls, humans build powerlines allowing them to extend their infrastructure to their boundries to build turrets, units are your standard stuff infantry then up to tanks then aircraft and your Ultimate units, both play roughly the same.  The only thing that really stands out in this game are the cutscenes, where they clearly spent the vast majority of their funds, each mission before and after has a cutscene which are top notch, sadly the story on the whole is kinda bad or rather its not horrible but its left terribly incomplete and considering they're releasing DLC, which i'm not paying for 3 missions i can only imagine they'll want to milk people for more money to get the rest, not sure why anyone in their right mind would do that though.  TLDR- The game is slow and clunky, the Goo is the worst faction i've played, the Campaign is insanely short 7.8 hours for me to finish, the Units are uninspired, and the only good thing about it is the cutscenes and story which is left completely unfinished. Should be a 20 dollar title.

RTS and civ building games are my favorite type of games, so I was rather excited to try a new RTS game. My friend and I have been playing Command & Conquer together for nearly ten years, and we've been looking for a new RTS to try, so I thought I'd give Grey Goo a chance.  The Ffactions are unique enough from one another, they build completely different, distinct looks, etc. and the game is quite beautiful graphically. Sadly that's the only good thing I have to say, since the game seems to push you to be a fast and aggressive player which I generally tend to play as a turtle. There's basically no base expansion aside from resource gathering and finding a big enough space so you can build your war factory and attached all the neccesary bits to it so you can produce everything. Resources are slow and limited, which adds to not being able to expand much.   To me it seems this game was designed around the idea of quick, simple RTS games with others in online multiplayer, and to that effect a lot of the driving content, such as diverse units, structures and the ability to not only push your army forward but your base forward as well, is not present.  You got the butter without the bread.

War might be evolving (as the game's tagline says), but some game developers are clearly not.  It's 2015 and the game doesn't let you click on the the terrain and drag to pan the view (you have to move the cursor to the edges of the screen). Also, can't tilt the camera, can't pause the game while panning the view or trying to select individual units, etc.. Overall, the UI seems designed by people who haven't played any game or used any 3D application or mapping software made in this century.  Buy only if you enjoy fighting against the UI instead of fighting the enemy units.  Also, it has the worst performance (lowest frame rate / highest GPU utilization) of any RTS I've ever played. The graphics don't look  bad , and the game is still playable (well, if you can put up with the prehistoric UI), but plenty of other games look better  and  have better performance.

Grey Goo seems okay, and it can be fun, but the campaign is awful and their storytelling is pretty bad  *THINGS* are happening all the time and there are characters who look like they are doing something, but it gives me no idea who these people are and why I should even care. The pacing is constantly set on BALLS-TO-THE-WALLS mode and doesn't give you any breathing room at all.   This is echoed by the campaign's level design as well with enemies constantly attacking you from every angle, every mission, and basically requires you to have quick reflexes non-stop. I've played through the first 5 missions and so far there have been very little variety --Each mission played just like the last.  It's a shame because they clearly spent a lot of time on the fully rendered cutscenes between each mission but they add absolutely nothing to the game at all. Every one of them left me confused and thinking 'That's it? Why even bother?'. It's such a tremendous waste of time and effort.  The last straw was the game crashing when I tried to save. I couldn't muster up the motivation to continue playing since.

My lack of reccomendation exists on the premise that you already own StarCraft II. If you don't, please ignore that and consider picking up this title.  I bought this game looking for a fun and visually-vibrant twist on StarCraft II, a game I've probably put over 100 hours into (a casual glance, I know). What I found instead was literally StarCraft II. Most everything is visually indistinguishable from a very slightly modded SCII UI, and that really dissappointed me. The voice overs, from the way communiqués appear in portraits to the voiceovers for the unit reactions, the resource harvesting system, it all just felt so boring to me after already having played SCII as much as I wanted; I didn't want to spend $50 to play it again.  If you love the SCII gameplay and want more of the same with a less rich story that has a lot less history and depth to it but with some very nice CGI, grab this on a sale, otherwise, avoid.

I believe there is a huge following to RTS games. I have played almost every rts game to date. This game slightly fills the huge gap of non existing new rts games. The game plays well singleplayer and with decent graphics. However, multiplayer is another story, games tend to disconnect. Multiplayer is segregated by region, so good luck finding games. The factions are extremely unbalanced, good luck defeating the 'goo' no matter which strategy you take. For example, 'goo' artillery and Anti Air can climb walls and mountains. The other factions can SEE ONLY with expensive AIRCRAFT that wouldent be able to damage a cute rabbit let alone units designated to anti-air. There is no such thing as rushing unless you are 'goo'. Multiplayer can be slow at times and it is difficult to adapt to changes in strategy, unless you are the 'goo'. if you prepare for a rush and arent rushed you will be screwed in the long run no matter what. Have fun finding a balance of multiplayer play in this game, for its impossible. My verdict, this game is more luck then strategy. You will fight blindly, stick to your set strategy from the start and try to follow through and hopefully it will counter your enemys strategy. Roll the dice.

Plagued with the same glaring issues that most every RTS has.   -Your units are stupid and won't do anything effectively without micromanaging the hell out of them using macros and bidning them and babysitting them constantly. You can select a group of units and tell them to walk in a direction. The fast ones won't slow down for the slower ones and end up trickeling into their own demise. They will also walk past enemies that are firing on them and ignore them as they die. If you use attack move, they will stop and fire at any stupid 10billion health wall and never get to their destination. You have to micro manager them like crazy to get anything done. Its just a huge wall of unnessiary ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t to have to learn to get into the genre, and I hate it. There should be many variations of attack move, and ways to command your units to do things more intelligently rather than babysitting them when you want to focus on something else. The mark of a good RTS player is that they can not only do this, but do it in many places at once while still focusing on the big picture (macro) which brings me to my next huge complaint.  The macro is the same old same old remember an exact set of openings and folling them to a T as fast as you possible can.   It pisses me off that a game with STRATEGY in the name of the genre is more about memorizing optimal patterns, repeating them hundreds of times so you can do them faster than the next guy, and honing your ability to click hundreds of times and minute (most of which are just directing your braindead units to doing the most simplest of takss).   I was drawn to this game because it was hyped to fix the issues with the direction RTS games have taken. It was said to put the strategy back in to RTS and take it away from being what the genre really should be named... CPM (Clicks per minute) because that is all this genre is.

I've played just about every decent title of RTS games since the late 90's. This game falls under the category of OKAY. With that being said, I can not recommend the game at it's current price of $50. There are 3 factions, each very unique. There is a decent amount of units, and the game feels fairly balanced. The main con to me is that its just not very exciting. I'm not one to normally gripe about graphics, but the battle animations are boring. Theres no cool explosions, no cool unit movements, etc. I have not played enough of the game to make the following assumption, but I have a feeling that the only thing it takes to win a battle of Grey Goo is having a higher number of units, and not necessarily a batter strategy. For that reason, and for the $50 price tag, I do not recommend the game. Wait for the price to go down. Check out Supreme Commander 1, Supreme Commander 2 as other options for now.
